repo_info: If $\tuple {x, y}$ is an [[Definition:Ordered Pair|ordered pair]] such that $\tuple {x, y} \in \RR$, we use the notation: :$s \mathrel \RR t$ or: :$\map \RR {s, t}$ and can say: :'''   ''' :'''   ''' If $\tuple {s, t} \notin \RR$, we can write: $s \not \mathrel \RR t$, that is, by drawing a line through the relation symbol. See [[Definition:Complement of Relation|Complement of Relation]].

Let $\varphi : A \to B$ be a continuous ring homomorphism between adic Noetherian topological rings, i.e., $\varphi$ is an arrow of $\textit{WAdm}^{Noeth}$. We say $\varphi$ is '''   ''' if the equivalent conditions of Lemma \ref{lemma-rig-smooth-continuous} hold.

A '''   ''' is a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]] with a [[Definition:Countable|countable]] number of [[Definition:Node of Tree|nodes]], in which a particular [[Definition:Node of Tree|node]] is [[Definition:Distinguish|distinguished]] from the others and called the '''   ''': :[[File:RootedTree.png|300px]]

Let $P$ be a property of ring maps. \begin{enumerate} \item We say that $P$ is '''   ''' if the following hold: \begin{enumerate} \item For any ring map $R \to A$, and any $f \in R$ we have $P(R \to A) \Rightarrow P(R_f \to A_f)$. \item For any rings $R$, $A$, any $f \in R$, $a\in A$, and any ring map $R_f \to A$ we have $P(R_f \to A) \Rightarrow P(R \to A_a)$. \item For any ring map $R \to A$, and $a_i \in A$ such that $(a_1, \ldots, a_n) = A$ then $\forall i, P(R \to A_{a_i}) \Rightarrow P(R \to A)$. \end{enumerate} \item We say that $P$ is '''   ''' if for any ring maps $R \to A$, $R \to R'$ we have $P(R \to A) \Rightarrow P(R' \to R' \otimes_R A)$. \item We say that $P$ is '''   ''' if for any ring maps $A \to B$, $B \to C$ we have $P(A \to B) \wedge P(B \to C) \Rightarrow P(A \to C)$. \end{enumerate}

A '''   ''' is a [[Definition:Quaternion|quaternion]] whose components are all either: :[[Definition:Integer|integers]] or: :[[Definition:Integer|integers]] plus a half, that is, halves of [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd integers]]. The set $H$ of all '''   ''' can therefore be defined as: :$H = \left\{{a + b \mathbf i + c \mathbf j + d \mathbf k \in \Bbb H: \left({a, b, c, d \in \Z}\right) \text { or } \left({a, b, c, d \in \Z + \dfrac 1 2}\right)}\right\}$

Let $f : \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{Y}$ be a morphism of algebraic stacks. \begin{enumerate} \item We say $f$ is '''   ''' if the map of topological spaces $|\mathcal{X}| \to |\mathcal{Y}|$ is closed. \item We say $f$ is '''   ''' if for every morphism of algebraic stacks $\mathcal{Z} \to \mathcal{Y}$ the morphism of topological spaces $$ |\mathcal{Z} \times_\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X}| \to |\mathcal{Z}| $$ is closed, i.e., the base change $\mathcal{Z} \times_\mathcal{Y} \mathcal{X} \to \mathcal{Z}$ is closed. \end{enumerate}

Let $X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n$ be [[Definition:Random Variable|random variables]].  Let the [[Definition:Joint Probability Distribution|joint distribution]] of $X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n$ be indexed by a [[Definition:Population Parameter|population parameter]] $\theta$.  Let $\delt(A) \R^n \to \R$ be a [[Definition:Real Function|real-valued function]].  The [[Definition:Random Variable|random variable]] $\hat \theta = \map \delta {X_1, X_2, \ldots, X_n}$ is called an '''   ''' of $\theta$.  A particular [[Definition:Realization of a Random Variable|realization]] of $\hat \theta$ is called an '''   ''' of $\theta$.

Let $\sim$ be the [[Definition:Equivalence Relation|equivalence relation]] on $T$ defined as: :$x \sim y \iff x$ and $y$ are [[Definition:Path-Connected Points|path-connected]]. The [[Definition:Equivalence Class|equivalence classes]] of $\sim$ are called the '''   '''. If $x \in T$, then the '''   ''' containing $x$ (that is, the set of points $y \in T$ with $x \sim y$) can be denoted by $\map {\operatorname{PC}_x} T$.

The '''   ''' of a presheaf of sets $\mathcal{F}$ over a site $\mathcal{C}$ is the set $$ \Gamma(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{F}) = \Mor_'''   '''(\mathcal{C})}(*, \mathcal{F}) $$ where $*$ is the final object in the category of presheaves on $\mathcal{C}$, i.e., the presheaf which associates to every object a singleton.

An '''   ''' is a [[Definition:Statement|statement]] which is introduced into an [[Definition:Logical Argument|argument]], whose [[Definition:Truth Value|truth value]] is (temporarily) accepted as [[Definition:True|True]]. In mathematics, the keyword '''   ''' is often the indicator here that an assumption is going to be introduced. For example: :'''   ''' (be true) ... can be interpreted, in [[Definition:Natural Language|natural language]], as: :'''   ''' ...

Let $S$ be a scheme. Let $(G, m)$ be a group scheme over $S$. \begin{enumerate} \item A '''   ''' of $G$ is a closed subscheme $H \subset G$ such that $m|_{H \times_S H}$ factors through $H$ and induces a group scheme structure on $H$ over $S$. \item An '''   ''' of $G$ is an open subscheme $G' \subset G$ such that $m|_{G' \times_S G'}$ factors through $G'$ and induces a group scheme structure on $G'$ over $S$. \end{enumerate}

Let $\struct {K, +_K, \times_K}$ be a [[Definition:Division Ring|division ring]]. Let $\struct {G, +_G}$ be an [[Definition:Abelian Group|abelian group]]. Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_K$ be a [[Definition:Unitary Module|unitary $K$-module]]. Then $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_K$ is a '''   ''' or a '''   '''. That is, a vector space is a [[Definition:Unitary Module|unitary module]] whose [[Definition:Scalar Ring of Unitary Module|scalar ring]] is a [[Definition:Division Ring|division ring]].

Let $S$ be a scheme. Let $f : X \to Y$ be a morphism of algebraic spaces over $S$. Let $\Delta_{X/Y} : X \to X \times_Y X$ be the diagonal morphism. \begin{enumerate} \item We say $f$ is '''   ''' if $\Delta_{X/Y}$ is a closed immersion. \item We say $f$ is '''   '''\footnote{In the literature this term often refers to quasi-separated and locally separated morphisms.} if $\Delta_{X/Y}$ is an immersion. \item We say $f$ is '''   ''' if $\Delta_{X/Y}$ is quasi-compact. \end{enumerate}
A scheme $X$ is called '''   ''' if $X$ is nonempty and for every nonempty affine open $U \subset X$ the ring $\Gamma(U, \mathcal{O}_X) = \mathcal{O}_X(U)$ is a domain.

Each [[Definition:Side of Polygon|side]] of a [[Definition:Polygon|polygon]] [[Definition:Intersection (Geometry)|intersects]] two other [[Definition:Side of Polygon|sides]], and so is terminated at either [[Definition:Endpoint of Line|endpoint]] by two [[Definition:Vertex of Polygon|vertices]]. The two [[Definition:Vertex of Polygon|vertices]] that terminate a particular [[Definition:Side of Polygon|side]] are referred to as the '''   ''' of that [[Definition:Side of Polygon|side]], or described as '''   ''' that [[Definition:Side of Polygon|side]].
Let $S$ be [[Definition:Uncountable Set|uncountable]]. Then $\tau_p$ is an '''   ''', and $\struct {S, \tau_p}$ is an '''   '''.

The '''   ''' of an '''   ''' is the [[Definition:Radius of Circle|radius]] of the larger of the $2$ [[Definition:Concentric Circles|concentric circles]] that form its [[Definition:Boundary (Geometry)|boundary]]. In the above diagram, the '''   ''' is denoted $R$.

Take a [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]], and remove all the [[Definition:Node of Tree|nodes]] whose [[Definition:Degree of Vertex|degree]] is $1$, along with all their [[Definition:Incident (Undirected Graph)|incident]] [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edges]]. Repeat the process until either: :One [[Definition:Node of Tree|node]] is left or: :Two [[Definition:Node of Tree|nodes]] are left, joined by a single [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]]. If one [[Definition:Node of Tree|node]] is left, it is called the '''   ''' of the [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. If two [[Definition:Node of Tree|nodes]] are left, joined by a single [[Definition:Edge of Graph|edge]], this is called the '''   ''' of the [[Definition:Tree (Graph Theory)|tree]]. === [[Definition:Central Tree|Central Tree]] === {{:Definition:Central Tree}} === [[Definition:Bicentral Tree|Bicentral Tree]] === {{:Definition:Bicentral Tree}}

A '''   ''', or just '''   ''', is a concept in [[Definition:Mathematical Logic|mathematical logic]]. Let $U$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Logical Formula|logical formulas]]. Let $\map \TT U$ be the [[Definition:Set|set]] of all [[Definition:Logical Formula|logical formulas]] $P$ such that $P$ is a [[Definition:Semantic Consequence|semantic consequence]] of $U$. That is, let $\map \TT U = \set {P: U \models P}$. Then $\TT$ is called '''   '''. The [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $\map \TT U$ are called [[Definition:Theorem|theorems]] of $U$. The [[Definition:Element|elements]] of $U$ are called the [[Definition:Axiom|axioms]] of $\map \TT U$.

Let $S$ be a scheme, and let $X$ be an algebraic space over $S$. A '''   ''' is a family of morphisms $\{f_i : X_i \to X\}_{i \in I}$ of algebraic spaces over $S$ such that each $f_i$ is syntomic and such that $$ |X| = \bigcup\nolimits_{i \in I} |f_i|(|X_i|), $$ i.e., the morphisms are jointly surjective.

Let $\struct {X, \circ}$ be a [[Definition:B-Algebra|$B$-algebra]]. Then $\struct {X, \circ}$ is said to be '''   ''' (or just '''   ''') {{iff}}: :$\forall x, y \in X: x \circ (0 \circ y) = y \circ (0 \circ x)$

The '''   ''' is measured only approximately in [[Definition:Length of Time|duration]], and is not used as a scientific measure. :$1$ '''   ''' $= 3$ [[Definition:Month|months]], although exactly which [[Definition:Month|months]] fall into which '''   ''' depends on the locale and the culture.

Let $G$ be a [[Definition:Group|group]]. Let $X$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]]. Let $\phi : G \times X \to X$ be a [[Definition:Group Action|group action]]. Let $H \le G$ be a [[Definition:Subgroup|subgroup]]. The '''   ''' is the [[Definition:Restriction|restriction]] of $\phi$ to $H \times X$. Equivalently, the '''   ''' is the [[Definition:Group Action|group action]] associated to the [[Definition:Permutation Representation|permutation representation]]: :$\rho \circ \iota : H \to \struct {\map \Gamma X, \circ}$ where: :$\iota : H \to G$ is the [[Definition:Inclusion Homomorphism|inclusion homomorphism]] :$\rho$ is the  [[Definition:Permutation Representation|permutation representation]] of $\phi$ :$\struct {\map \Gamma X, \circ}$ is the [[Definition:Symmetric Group|symmetric group]] on $X$.

In the situation of Lemma \ref{lemma-at-the-bottom-etale} the functor $i_X^{-1} = \pi_{X, *}$ is often called the '''   ''', and for a sheaf $\mathcal{F}$ on the big \'etale site we often denote $\mathcal{F}|_{X_\etale}$ this restriction.

The '''   ''' is the [[Definition:Diophantine Equation|Diophantine equation]]: :$x^2 + y^2 = z^2$ where $x, y, z$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]] such that $x, y, z > 0$. Solutions of this equation are known as [[Definition:Pythagorean Triple|Pythagorean triples]]. If, in addition, $\left({x, y, z}\right)$ is a [[Definition:Primitive Pythagorean Triple|primitive Pythagorean triple]], then $\left({x, y, z}\right)$ is known as a '''   ''' of $x^2 + y^2 = z^2$.
A topological space is '''   ''' if the connected components are all singletons.

Let $\mathcal{A}$ be an additive category. A '''   ''' is a morphism of complexes such that each $A^n \to B^n$ is isomorphic to the inclusion of a direct summand. A '''   ''' is a morphism of complexes such that each $B^n \to C^n$ is isomorphic to the projection onto a direct summand.

A '''   ''' is an interpretation of the [[Definition:Metacategory|metacategory axioms]] within [[Definition:Set Theory|set theory]]. Because a [[Definition:Metacategory|metacategory]] is a [[Definition:Metagraph|metagraph]], this means that a '''   ''' is a [[Definition:Graph (Category Theory)|graph]]. Let $\mathfrak U$ be a [[Definition:Class (Class Theory)|class]] of [[Definition:Set|sets]]. A [[Definition:Metacategory|metacategory]] $\mathbf C$ is a '''   ''' {{iff}}: :$(1): \quad$ The [[Definition:Object|objects]] form a subset $\mathbf C_0$ or $\operatorname {ob} \ \CC \subseteq \mathfrak U$ :$(2): \quad$ The [[Definition:Morphism (Category Theory)|morphisms]] form a subset $\mathbf C_1$ or $\operatorname{mor} \ \mathbf C$ or $\operatorname{Hom} \ \mathbf C \subseteq \mathfrak U$

Let $S$ be a scheme and let $X$ be an algebraic space over $S$. Let $\mathcal{F}$ be a quasi-coherent $\mathcal{O}_X$-module. Let $x \in |X|$. Let $d \in \{0, 1, 2, \ldots, \infty\}$. We say '''   '''$ has length $d$ at $x$} if the equivalent conditions of Lemma \ref{lemma-length} are satisfied.

Every [[Definition:Even Integer|even integer]] is [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divisible]] by $2$ (because this is the definition of '''   '''). Therefore, apart from $2$ itself, all [[Definition:Prime Number|primes]] are [[Definition:Odd Integer|odd]]. So, referring to an '''   ''' is a convenient way of specifying that a number is a [[Definition:Prime Number|prime number]], but not equal to $2$.

'''   ''' (or just '''   ''') is a word used to mean '''   '''. The intuitive belief is that space is [[Definition:Dimension (Geometry)|$3$-dimensional]] and therefore [[Definition:Isomorphism (Abstract Algebra)|isomorphic]] to the [[Definition:Real Vector Space|real vector space $\R^3$]]. Hence '''   ''' is usually taken as an alternative term for [[Definition:Euclidean Space|Euclidean $3$-dimensional space]].

A '''   ''' $T$ is given by $$ n, m_i, a_{ij}, w_i, g_i $$ where $n \geq 1$ is an integer and $m_i$, $a_{ij}$, $w_i$, $g_i$ are integers for $1 \leq i, j \leq n$ subject to the following conditions \begin{enumerate} \item $m_i > 0$, $w_i > 0$, $g_i \geq 0$, \item the matrix $A = (a_{ij})$ is symmetric and $a_{ij} \geq 0$ for $i \not = j$, \item there is no proper nonempty subset $I \subset \{1, \ldots, n\}$ such that $a_{ij} = 0$ for $i \in I$, $j \not \in I$, \item for each $i$ we have $\sum_j a_{ij}m_j = 0$, and \item $w_i | a_{ij}$. \end{enumerate}

Let $R \to S$ be a ring map. The ring $S' \subset S$ of elements integral over $R$, see Lemma \ref{lemma-integral-closure-is-ring}, is called the '''   ''' of $R$ in $S$. If $R \subset S$ we say that $R$ is '''   ''' in $S$ if $R = S'$.

[[Definition:Line Segment|Straight lines]] are '''   ''' when the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|squares]] on them are [[Definition:Divisor of Real Number|measured]] by the same [[Definition:Area|area]], and '''   ''' when the [[Definition:Square (Geometry)|squares]] on them cannot possibly have any [[Definition:Area|area]] as a [[Definition:Common Divisor of Real Numbers|common measure]].

The '''   ''' of a [[Definition:Physical Process|physical process]] is its [[Definition:Derivative|(first) derivative]] with respect to [[Definition:Time|time]]. Loosely speaking, it means '''   ''', with a wider scope than change in [[Definition:Displacement|physical displacement]]. === [[Definition:Rate/Dimension|Dimension]] === {{:Definition:Rate/Dimension}} [[Category:Definitions/Dimensions of Measurement]] tt43pngp41nnkp4tbffuxe13olzp1e3

A triple $(\mathcal{C}, \otimes, \phi)$ where $\mathcal{C}$ is a category, $\otimes : \mathcal{C} \times \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{C}$ is a functor, and $\phi$ is an associativity constraint is called a '''   ''' if there exists a unit $\mathbf{1}$.
A '''   ''' is a category where every morphism is an isomorphism.

An '''   ''' is also known as a '''   '''. Among ancient Greek philosophers, the term '''   ''' was used for a general truth that was common to everybody (see [[Axiom:Euclid's Common Notions|Euclid's "common notions"]]), while  '''   ''' had a specific application to the subject under discussion. For most authors, the distinction is no longer used, and the terms are generally used interchangeably. This is the position of {{ProofWiki}}. However, some believe there is a difference significant enough to matter: :''... we shall use "postulate" instead of "axiom" hereafter, as "axiom" has a pernicious historical association of "self-evident, necessary truth", which "postulate" does not have; a postulate is an arbitrary assumption laid down by the mathematician himself and not by God Almighty.'' :::: -- {{BookReference|Men of Mathematics|1937|Eric Temple Bell}}: Chapter $\text{II}$: Modern Minds in Ancient Bodies

Let $R$ be a ring. Let $M$ be an $R$-module. \begin{enumerate} \item A (left) '''   ''' $F_\bullet \to M$ of $M$ is an exact complex $$ \ldots \to F_2 \to F_1 \to F_0 \to M \to 0 $$ of $R$-modules. \item A '''   ''' is a resolution $F_\bullet \to M$ where each $F_i$ is a free $R$-module. \item A '''   ''' is a resolution $F_\bullet \to M$ where each $F_i$ is a finite free $R$-module. \end{enumerate}

Let $f : X \to S$ be a family of curves with Cohen-Macaulay fibres equidimensional of dimension $1$ (Lemma \ref{lemma-CM-1-curves}). Then the $\mathcal{O}_X$-module $$ \omega_{X/S} = H^{-1}(\omega_{X/S}^\bullet) $$ studied in Lemma \ref{lemma-CM-dualizing} is called the '''   ''' of $f$.

A '''   ''' is a [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|strictly positive real number]] which is the [[Definition:Mean Proportional|mean proportional]] between two [[Definition:Rational Line Segment|rational line segments]] which are [[Definition:Commensurable in Square Only|commensurable in square only]]. Thus a [[Definition:Strictly Positive Real Number|magnitude]] $a \in \R_{>0}$ is '''   ''' {{iff}} $a$ is of the form: :$a = \rho \sqrt [4] k$ where: : $\rho$ is a [[Definition:Rational Number|rational number]] : $k$ is a [[Definition:Rational Number|rational number]] whose [[Definition:Square Root|square root]] is [[Definition:Irrational Number|irrational]]. {{:Euclid:Proposition/X/21}}

Let $n\geq1$ be a [[Definition:Natural Number|natural number]]. Let $a_1, \ldots, a_n, b_1, \ldots, b_n$ be [[Definition:Real Number|real numbers]]. The [[Definition:Cartesian Product|Cartesian product]] of [[Definition:Closed Interval|closed intervals]]: :$\displaystyle \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^n \left[{a_i \,.\,.\, b_i}\right] = \left[{a_1 \,.\,.\, b_1}\right] \times \cdots \times \left[{a_n \,.\,.\, b_n}\right] \subseteq \R^n$ is called a '''   ''' or '''   '''. === Degenerate Case === In case $a_i > b_i$ for some $i$, the rectangle is taken to be the [[Definition:Empty Set|empty set]] $\varnothing$. This is in accordance with the result [[Cartesian Product is Empty iff Factor is Empty]] for general [[Definition:Cartesian Product|Cartesian products]].

Let $x \in \R: x < 0$. We take the [[Definition:Absolute Value|absolute value]] $y$ of $x$, that is: :$y = \size x$ Then we take the '''   ''': :$\size {s . d_1 d_2 d_3 \ldots}_b$ where $s = \floor y$. Finally, the '''   ''' is defined as: :$-\sqbrk {s . d_1 d_2 d_3 \ldots}_b$

Let $I$ be a preordered set. We say a system (resp.\ inverse system) $(M_i, f_{ii'})$ is a '''   ''' (resp.\ '''   ''') if $I$ is a directed set (Definition \ref{definition-directed-set}): $I$ is nonempty and for all $i_1, i_2 \in I$ there exists $i\in I$ such that $i_1 \leq i$ and $i_2 \leq i$.
Let $f : X \to S$ be a morphism of schemes. We say $f$ is '''   ''' if $f$ satisfies the equivalent conditions of Lemma \ref{lemma-nodal-family}.

Let $\left({M_1, d_1}\right)$ and $\left({M_2, d_2}\right)$ be [[Definition:Metric Space|metric spaces]]. Let $\alpha \in \R_{\ge 0}$ be a [[Definition:Positive Real Number|positive real number]]. A [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] $f: M_1 \to M_2$ is said to be '''   ''' {{iff}}: :$\exists L \in \R_{\ge 0}: \forall x, y \in M_1: d_2 \left({f \left({x}\right), f \left({y}\right)}\right) \le L \left({d_1 \left({x, y}\right)}\right)^\alpha$ Further, $f$ is said to be '''   ''' {{iff}} it is '''   ''' for some $\alpha \in \R_{\ge 0}$.

Let $F, G : \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{B}$ be functors. A '''   ''', or a '''   ''' $t : F \to G$, is a collection $\{t_x\}_{x\in \Ob(\mathcal{A})}$ such that \begin{enumerate} \item $t_x : F(x) \to G(x)$ is a morphism in the category $\mathcal{B}$, and \item for every morphism $\phi : x \to y$ of $\mathcal{A}$ the following diagram is commutative $$ \xymatrix{ F(x) \ar[r]^{t_x} \ar[d]_{F(\phi)} & G(x) \ar[d]^{G(\phi)} \\ F(y) \ar[r]^{t_y} & G(y) } $$ \end{enumerate}

Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite set]] of [[Definition:Integer|integers]], that is: :$S = \set {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n: \forall k \in \N^*_n: x_k \in \Z}$ Let $c \in \Z$ such that $c$ [[Definition:Divisor of Integer|divides]] all the elements of $S$, that is: :$\forall x \in S: c \divides x$ Then $c$ is a '''   ''' (or '''   ''') of all the [[Definition:Element|elements]] in $S$.

(See Morphisms, Definition \ref{morphisms-definition-unramified} for the definition in the general case.) Let $Y$ be a locally Noetherian scheme. Let $f : X \to Y$ be locally of finite type. Let $x \in X$. \begin{enumerate} \item We say $f$ is '''   ''' if $\mathcal{O}_{Y, f(x)} \to \mathcal{O}_{X, x}$ is an unramified homomorphism of local rings. \item The morphism $f : X \to Y$ is said to be '''   ''' if it is unramified at all points of $X$. \end{enumerate}

(See Topologies, Definitions \ref{topologies-definition-standard-fppf}, \ref{topologies-definition-standard-syntomic}, \ref{topologies-definition-standard-smooth}, \ref{topologies-definition-standard-etale}, and \ref{topologies-definition-standard-Zariski}.) Let $\tau \in \{fppf, syntomic, smooth, \etale, Zariski\}$. Let $T$ be an affine scheme. A '''   ''' of $T$ is a family $\{f_j : U_j \to T\}_{j = 1, \ldots, m}$ with each $U_j$ is affine, and each $f_j$ flat and of finite presentation, standard syntomic, standard smooth, \'etale, resp.\ the immersion of a standard principal open in $T$ and $T = \bigcup f_j(U_j)$.

Let $x_0$ be an [[Definition:Equilibrium Point|equilibrium point]] of the [[Definition:System of Differential Equations|system]] $x' = f \left({x}\right)$. Then a function $V$ is a '''   ''' of the system on an open set $U$ containing the equilibrium [[Definition:Iff|iff]]: * $V \left({x_0}\right) = 0$ * $V \left({x}\right) > 0$ if $x \in U \setminus \left\{{x_0}\right\}$ * $\nabla V \cdot f \le 0$ for $x \in U$. {{explain|What $\nabla$ means in this context.}} If the inequality is [[Definition:Strict Inequality|strict]] except at $x_0$, then $V$ is '''   '''.

Let $A$ be a Noetherian ring. \begin{enumerate} \item If $A$ is local, then we say $A$ is a '''   ''' if its completion is a complete intersection in the sense above. \item In general we say $A$ is a '''   ''' if all of its local rings are complete intersections. \end{enumerate}

Let $\mathcal{X}$ be an algebraic stack. A '''   ''' of $\mathcal{X}$ is an equivalence class of morphisms from spectra of fields into $\mathcal{X}$. The set of points of $\mathcal{X}$ is denoted $|\mathcal{X}|$.

'''   ''' is the study of [[Definition:Point|points]], [[Definition:Line|lines]], [[Definition:Surface|surfaces]] and [[Definition:Volume|volumes]] in [[Definition:Ordinary Space|real space]], and is based on the concepts of [[Definition:Distance (Linear Measure)|distance]] and [[Definition:Angle|angle]]. It is what is usually understood in the everyday world as '''   ''' proper.

Let $X$ be a locally Noetherian integral scheme. \begin{enumerate} \item A '''   ''' is an integral closed subscheme $Z \subset X$ of codimension $1$. \item A '''   ''' is a formal sum $D = \sum n_Z Z$ where the sum is over prime divisors of $X$ and the collection $\{Z \mid n_Z \not = 0\}$ is locally finite (Topology, Definition \ref{topology-definition-locally-finite}). \end{enumerate} The group of all Weil divisors on $X$ is denoted $\text{Div}(X)$.
If $G / H$ is a [[Definition:Finite Set|finite set]], then $\index G H$ is '''   ''', and $H$ is '''   ''' in $G$.

Let $G$ be a [[Definition:Group|group]]. Let $H$ be a [[Definition:Subgroup|subgroup]] of $G$. Then $H$ is a '''   ''' {{iff}} the [[Definition:Generator of Subgroup|subgroup generated]] by $H$ and any [[Definition:Conjugate of Group Subset|conjugate]] of $H$ is also [[Definition:Generator of Subgroup|generated]] by $H$ and a [[Definition:Conjugate of Group Subset|conjugate]] of $H$ within that [[Definition:Generator of Subgroup|generated subgroup]]. That is, $H$ is '''   ''' {{iff}}: : $\forall g \in G: \exists k \in \left\langle{H, H^g}\right\rangle: \left\langle{H, H^k}\right\rangle = \left\langle{H, H^g}\right\rangle$ where: : $\left\langle{H, H^g}\right\rangle$ is the [[Definition:Generator of Subgroup|subgroup generated]] by $H$ and $H^g$ : $H^g$ is the [[Definition:Conjugate of Group Subset|conjugate]] of $H$ by $g$.
Let $T$ be a scheme. A '''   ''' is a family of morphisms $\{f_i : T_i \to T\}_{i \in I}$ of schemes such that each $f_i$ is smooth and such that $T = \bigcup f_i(T_i)$.
Let $S$ be an [[Definition:Infinite Set|infinite set]]. Then $\tau = \powerset S$ is an '''   ''', and $\struct {S, \tau} = \struct {S, \powerset S}$ is an '''   '''.

Let $(X, \mathcal{O}_X)$ be a ringed space. Let $\mathcal{F}$, $\mathcal{G}$ be $\mathcal{O}_X$-modules. The '''   ''''s of $\mathcal{F}$ and $\mathcal{G}$ are define by the formula $$ \text{Tor}_p^'''   '''_X}(\mathcal{F}, \mathcal{G}) = H^{-p}(\mathcal{F} \otimes_'''   '''_X}^\mathbf{L} \mathcal{G}) $$ with derived tensor product as defined above.
'''   ''' is the application of the rules of conventional '''   ''' in order to manipulate '''   '''.
A module $M$ over $R$ is said to be of '''   ''' over $R$ if it  is isomorphic to the cokernel of a map of finite free modules $ R^'''   ''' \to R^'''   '''$.

Suppose that $I$ is a set, and suppose given for every $i \in I$ an object $M_i$ of the category $\mathcal{C}$. A '''   ''' $\coprod_{i\in I} M_i$ is by definition $\colim_\mathcal{I} M$ (if it exists) where $\mathcal{I}$ is the category having only identities as morphisms and having the elements of $I$ as objects.

A '''   ''' is an idealization of a computing machine. The idea goes as follows. A '''   ''' works by manipulating [[Definition:Symbol|symbols]] on an imaginary piece of paper by means of a specific set of [[Definition:Algorithm|algorithmic rules]].

Let $B \to S$ as in Section \ref{section-notation}. \begin{enumerate} \item A '''   ''' is a pair $(G, m)$, where $G$ is an algebraic space over $B$ and $m : G \times_B G \to G$ is a morphism of algebraic spaces over $B$ with the following property: For every scheme $T$ over $B$ the pair $(G(T), m)$ is a group. \item A {\it morphism $\psi : (G, m) \to (G', m')$ of group algebraic spaces over $B$} is a morphism $\psi : G \to G'$ of algebraic spaces over $B$ such that for every $T/B$ the induced map $\psi : G(T) \to G'(T)$ is a homomorphism of groups. \end{enumerate}

$\struct {S, \tau}$ is a '''   ''' or '''   ''' {{iff}}: :$\forall x, y \in S, x \ne y: \exists U, V \in \tau: x \in U, y \in V: U^- \cap V^- = \O$  That is, for any two [[Definition:Distinct Elements|distinct elements]] $x, y \in S$ there exist [[Definition:Open Set (Topology)|open sets]] $U, V \in \tau$ containing $x$ and $y$ respectively whose [[Definition:Closure (Topology)|closures]] are [[Definition:Disjoint Sets|disjoint]].

Let $X$ be a topological space. \begin{enumerate} \item  Let $x, y \in X$, $x \not = y$. Suppose $x \leadsto y$, that is $y$ is a specialization of $x$. We say $y$ is an '''   ''' of $x$ if there is no $z \in X \setminus \{x, y\}$ with $x \leadsto z$ and $z \leadsto y$. \item A map $\delta : X \to \mathbf{Z}$ is called a '''   '''\footnote{This is likely nonstandard notation. This notion is usually introduced only for (locally) Noetherian schemes, in which case condition (a) is implied by (b).} if \begin{enumerate} \item whenever $x \leadsto y$ and $x \not = y$ we have $\delta(x) > \delta(y)$, and \item for every immediate specialization $x \leadsto y$ in $X$ we have $\delta(x) = \delta(y) + 1$. \end{enumerate} \end{enumerate}

Let $X$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]], and let $f, g: X \to \overline{\R}$ be [[Definition:Extended Real-Valued Function|extended real-valued functions]]. Since the [[Definition:Ordering on Extended Real Numbers|ordering on $\overline{\R}$]] coincides on $\R$ with the standard ordering, this definition incorporates the [[Definition:Pointwise Minimum of Real-Valued Functions|definition for real-valued functions]].
Let $\mathcal{X}$ be an algebraic stack. The underlying '''   ''' of $\mathcal{X}$ is the set of points $|\mathcal{X}|$ endowed with the topology constructed in Lemma \ref{lemma-topology-points}.

Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Topological Space|topological space]]. Let $U \subseteq S$ be a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of $S$. Let $S$ be a scheme. Let $(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{O})$ be a ringed site. Let $(\mathcal{A}, \text{d})$ be a sheaf of differential graded algebras on $(\mathcal{C}, \mathcal{O})$. Let $\text{Qis}$ be as in Lemma \ref{lemma-qis}. The '''   ''', \text{d})$} is the triangulated category $$ D(\mathcal{A}, \text{d}) = \text{Qis}^{-1}K(\text{Mod}_{(A, \text{d})}) $$ discussed in more detail above.
Functions f and g, such that f is Lebesgue-Stieltjes integrable with respect to g but not Riemann-Stieltjes integrable.
The cancellation law of matrix multiplication does not hold, i.e., $A \neq O, A B=A C$ does not necessarily imply $B=C$
There exists a paracompact space that is not a compact space.
There exists an $(\mathbf{L})$ measurable function that is nowhere continuous and not $(\boldsymbol{B})$ measurable.

There exist two linear distances $d_{1}, d_{2}$ on a linear space X such that for any $\left\{x_{n}\right\} \subset X,\left\{x_{n}\right\}$, convergence is the same in both metrics, but there are no constants m, $M>0$, such that $m d_{1}(x, y) \leqslant d_{2}(x, y) \leqslant M d_{1}(x, y)$.

There exists a complex sequence $\left\{\lambda_{n}\right\} $ with accumulation point $\lambda=0$, for which it is impossible to construct a bounded integral operator $T$ on $L^{2}[0, +\infty)$ that is densely defined such that $\lambda_{i}(i=1,2, \cdots)$ are all eigenvalues of $T$, and for $t \in[0,+\infty)$, it holds that $\int_{0}^{+\infty}|K(t, s)|^{2} d s<+\infty$.
There exists a quasi-nilpotent operator T such that 0 does not belong to the numerical range of T.
There exist two compatible topologies, one of which is complete and the other is not complete.

There exists a sequence $\{\alpha_{n}\}$ that tends to zero, from which a bounded measurable function $f$ can be constructed such that $\left\{f\left(x-\alpha_{n}\right)\right\}$ does not converge everywhere to $f(x)$.
There exists a mapping from one topological space to another, which is closed but neither open nor continuous.
If the irreducible polynomial $p(x)$ is a $k$-fold factor of $f(x)$ $(k \geqslant 1)$, then $p(x)$ is a $k-1$ fold factor of $f^{\prime}(x)$. Provide an example showing the converse is not true.
There exists a separable metric space that is nowhere locally compact.
A decreasing sequence of continuous functions, if it converges to a continuous function at every point, it must be uniformly convergent.
There exists an inductive limit X of a family of locally convex spaces $X_{\alpha}$ such that some bounded set of X is not contained within any $X_{\alpha}$.
The condition of non-negativity of the function sequence in Levi's theorem cannot be removed.
There exist two different topologies on an infinite-dimensional linear space $X$, under which the continuous linear functionals on $X$ are the same.
There exists a non-negative measurable function not belonging to any $L^{p}(0,1)(p>0)$.
There exists a measurable function whose two (L) iterated integrals exist but are not equal.
There exists a sequence of bounded linear operators that converge weakly but not strongly.
Subnormal operators on infinite-dimensional Hilbert spaces must be hyponormal.
There exist two disjoint closed sets with distance zero.
There exists a locally convex Frchet space, its strong dual is neither a Mackey space nor a bornological space.
There exist two topologies $\tau_{1}$ and $\tau_{2}$ on a set X, with $\tau_{1}<\tau_{2}$, such that $\left(X, \tau_{1}\right)$ is separable and $\left(X, \tau_{2}\right)$ is not separable.
There exist two distances on a certain set such that one metric space is complete and the other is incomplete.
There exists a function on the Cantor set that is nowhere continuous but continuous on its neighboring intervals.
We know that in a finite group, the order of each element is finite. So if the order of every element in a group is finite, then the group is necessarily a finite group.
There exist two comparable but not equal norms on a certain linear space, such that the strong norm is a barrelled space while the weak norm is a Banach space.
There exists a reflexive Banach space without the Banach-Saks property.
The quotient space of a regular space must be a regular space.
There exists a measurable subset within the unit square that cannot be expressed as a countable union of 'rectangles'.

Given any divergent series of positive terms $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_{n}$, one can find a positive sequence $\left\{c_{n}\right\}$ converging to zero, such that $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} c_{n} a_{n}$ nonetheless diverges.
There exists a bounded function defined on a compact set without local extrema.
There exist Banach spaces with a basis but without an unconditional basis.
There exist countable $\sigma$-compact spaces whose product is not $\sigma$-compact.
There exists a planar point set E, on one hand E can be represented as the union of two disjoint sets A and B, on the other hand, E can be merged with A and B.
There exists a function defined on [0,1) and taking values in [0,1] that is nowhere continuous, and it takes all values in [0,1] on every arbitrarily small nonempty subinterval.
If $\alpha_{1}, \alpha_{2}, \cdots, \alpha_{r}$ are linearly independent, then any two different vectors among them must be linearly independent, and vice versa.
There exists a non-measurable function on $[0,1] \times[0,1]$ whose two (L) iterated integrals both exist and are equal.
There exists some integral operator that is a non-compact strictly singular operator.
There exists a function with a double limit and one iterated limit, while the other iterated limit does not exist.
There exists a sequence of sets $\left\{\boldsymbol{A}_{n}\right\}$ such that $\overline{\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} \boldsymbol{A}_{n}} \neq \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} \overline{\boldsymbol{A}}_{n}$.
There exists a discontinuous bilinear functional, which is continuous with respect to each variable individually.
There exists a regular but not completely regular topological space.
There exists a Banach space with a basis, whose conjugate space has no basis.
There exists a topological space that satisfies the first countability axiom, but one of its quotient spaces does not satisfy the first countability axiom.
There exist a function $ f(x, y)$ that, for every x, is a Borel measurable function of y, and for every y, is a Borel measurable function of x, but f(x, y) is not (L) measurable.
The definition of a subgroup requires subset $H$ to relate to the multiplication of group $G$, rather than saying subset $H$ forms a group with the multiplication of $H$.
There exists an additive continuous operator on some complex normed linear space that does not satisfy the condition of complex homogeneity.
There exists a mapping with a closed image whose image is not strongly closed.
There exist two linearly independent elements x and y in $l$(or $l^{\infty}$) such that $\|x-y\| \cdot\|x+y\| =\left|\|\boldsymbol{x}\|^{2}-\|\boldsymbol{y}\|^{2}\right|$.

There exists a non-negative (L) measurable function f on $R^{\prime}$, such that for any interval $(a, b) (a<b)$ and $r \in R^{\prime}$, it always holds that $\begin{array}{l}\quad \boldsymbol{m}\{(\boldsymbol{a}, \boldsymbol{b}) \cap\{\boldsymbol{x}: \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x}) \geqslant \boldsymbol{r}\}\}>\boldsymbol{0}, \\\text { but } \int_{\pi^{\prime}} f(x) d x \neq+\infty \end{array}$
The strong limit of a sequence of unitary operators exists, but it is not a unitary operator.

If $\mathrm{X}$ is a metric linear space, $\left\{x_{n}\right\} \subset X$ and $x_{n} \rightarrow 0 \quad(n \rightarrow \infty )$, then it follows that $\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{n} x_{k}}{n} \rightarrow 0(n \rightarrow \infty)$ .
There exists a Schauder basis of a certain Banach space that weakly converges to 0, but it does not have an unconditional basis sequence.
There exists an indeterminate form of complex-valued functions where L'Hospital's rule fails.

Let X be a Banach space, and let $B=\left\{\left(x_{a}, y_{a}\right): a \in A\right\} \subset X \times X^{*}$, where $\left(x_{a}, y_{a}\right)$ satisfies the condition: $y_{\beta}\left(x_{\alpha}\right)=\delta_{\alpha \beta}$. (1) Arsove and Edwards call B a generalized basis, meaning $\left\{x_{a}: \alpha \in A\right\}$ is linearly dense in X. (2) Davis calls B a conjugate generalized basis, meaning $\left\{y_{a}: \alpha \in A\right\}$ is linearly dense in $X^{*}$. Proposition: In Hilbert space, generalized basis and conjugate generalized basis do not contain each other.
There exists a Banach space that is not weakly sequentially complete.

Given any $f \in L[a, b]$, a set $A \subset [a, b]$ can be constructed such that $mA = b-a$, and for any $\boldsymbol{r} \in \mathbf{R}^{1}$ and any $x \in A$, we have $\lim_{h \rightarrow 0} \frac{1}{h} \int_{x}^{x+h}|f(t)-r| dt=|f(x)-r|$.
There exist nowhere continuous, weakly bounded variation functions defined on [0,1] and taking values in c.

There exists a non-negative upper semicontinuous function f on $[0,+\infty)$ such that $\int_{0}^{+\infty} f(x) dx = +\infty$, while for every $h>0$, $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} f(n \boldsymbol{h})<+\infty$.
There exists an algebraic direct sum of two normed subspaces in a certain locally convex space that cannot be metrized.
There exists a simple arc with no definable length.

For matrices $A 
eq O, B 
eq O$ where $AB = O$, there is also $BA = O$. Present an example where $A 
eq O, B 
eq O$ and $AB = O$, but $BA 
eq O$.
There exists a nowhere differentiable function f, such that $ \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} n\left[f\left(x+\frac{1}{n}\right)-f(x)\right] $ exists.
There exists a Banach space, whose norm is Gateaux differentiable at some point but not Frchet differentiable.
The $F_{\sigma}$ type sets are all closed.
There exists a Banach space with a bounded complete basis that is not somewhat reflexive.
There exist two invertible matrices whose product is not invertible.
There exists a discontinuous linear operator f from a normed linear space to itself, such that $\{\boldsymbol{x}: \boldsymbol{f}(\boldsymbol{x})=0\}$ is a closed set.

There exists a sequence of functions $\left\{f_{n}\right\}$ on [0,1], such that $\left|f_{n}\right|_{L^{r}[0,1]} \leqslant M(n=1, 2, \cdots), \left\{f_{n}\right\}$ converges pointwise to f on [0,1], but $\left.\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} \mid |f_{n}-f \|_{L^{r}[0,1]}\right. \neq 0$.
There exist two closed subspaces in a linear topological space whose sum is not closed.
For a function f, if $\lim _{h \rightarrow 0}[f(x-h)+f(x-h)-2 f(x)] / h^{2}$ exists, then $f^{\prime \prime}(x)$ also exists.
There exists a Banach space with the approximation property but without the bounded approximation property.
There exists a basis of a certain conjugate space $\boldsymbol{X}{ }^{*}$ does not have a biorthogonal sequence in X.
There exists a metric space in which the closure of an open ball is a closed ball, but a certain subspace of it does not have this property.
There exists a function series that converges uniformly but is nowhere absolutely convergent.

A sequence of sets $\left\{E_{n}\right\}$ is called decreasing if $E_{1} \supset E_{2} \supset \cdots \supset E_{n} \supset \cdots$. $\left\{E_{n}\right\}$ is called increasing if $E_{1} \subset E_{2} \subset \cdots \subset E_{n} \subset \cdots$. There exists a dense everywhere decreasing sequence on the line $\left\{\boldsymbol{E}_{n}\right\}$ such that $\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} \boldsymbol{E}_{n} =\varnothing$.
A first Baire class subspace in a Banach space, which itself is not a first Baire space.
There exists a separable Banach space with an inseparable dual space.
There exists a non-locally convex metric linear space on which there exists a non-zero continuous linear functional.
There exists a series of positive terms such that any positive rational number can be expressed as a sum of a finite number of its distinct terms.
There exists a compact subspace $E$ in some metric space such that every ball in $E$ is connected, but the closure of an open ball is not necessarily a closed ball.
Almost everywhere convergence and weak convergence do not imply each other.
If $p(x) \mid f(x) g(x)$ then $p(x) \mid f(x)$ or $p(x) \mid g(x)$.
There exists a subset A of ${R}^{1}$, such that every measurable subset of A and ${A}^{c}$ has measure zero.
There exists a non-discrete topological space where every compact set is a finite set.
The composite function is always definitely (R) integrable.
There exists a trigonometric series that converges on some countable set, but its coefficients do not tend to zero.
There exists a convergent monotonic uniformly bounded sequence of continuous functions whose limit function is not (R) integrable.
There exists a vector-valued function that is strongly continuous everywhere but weakly differentiable nowhere.

Let $\left\{A_{\alpha} \mid \alpha \in \Delta\right\}$ be a family of semi-open sets in a topological space $(X, \tau)$. If $\left\{A_{\alpha} \mid \alpha \in \Delta\right\}$ is a cover of X, it is called a semi-open cover or S-cover of X. A topological space X is called S-closed if for every S-cover $\left\{U_{\alpha}\right\}$, there exists a finite subset $\left\{U_{\alpha_{i}}\right\}_{i=1}^{n}$ such that $X \subset \bigcup_{i=1}^{n} \bar{U}_{\alpha{i}}$. There exists some S-closed space whose subspace is not S-closed.

Given any $G_{\sigma}$ type countable set E, a non-decreasing function f can be constructed, whose derivative satisfies the condition: $\boldsymbol{f}^{\prime}(\boldsymbol{x})=\infty(\boldsymbol{x} \in \boldsymbol{E}), \boldsymbol{f}^{\prime}(\boldsymbol{x})=\boldsymbol{0}(\boldsymbol{x} \bar{\in }E) $.
Similar matrices are definitely equivalent matrices, but not vice versa.
There exists a continuous image of a locally compact space that is not locally compact.

There exist two disjoint dense sets A and B within [0, 1] such that $[0, 1] = A \cup B$, and for any $\alpha, \beta (0 \leqslant \alpha < \beta \leqslant 1)$, the intersections $(\alpha, \beta) \cap A$ and $(\alpha, \beta) \cap B$ both have the cardinality of the continuum.
Given any two points x and y on the unit sphere S of a metric linear space, there exists some $z \in S$ such that $d(x, z) = d(z, y)$.

There exist weakly compactly generated spaces that are neither separable nor reflexive. That is, reflexive spaces are WCG spaces, separable spaces are also WCG spaces, but WCG spaces are neither necessarily reflexive nor separable.
There exists a divergent series, and it is impossible to accelerate its divergence by rearrangement.

In the second definition of a group, can the condition in item $\mathrm{V}$ be replaced by the following condition: $V^{\prime}$. For any element a of G, there can be found at least one left identity $e^{\prime}$ of G and an element $a^{-1}$ such that $a^{-1} a=e^{\prime}$. This condition exactly ignores the requirement that e is a fixed left identity.

There exists a function f on [0, 1] such that both the set A of its continuity points and the set B of its discontinuity points are dense in [0, 1], and for any open interval $(\alpha, \beta) \subset [0, 1]$, the intersections $A \cap (\alpha, \beta)$ and $B \cap (\alpha, \beta)$ both have the cardinality of the continuum.
$B=T^{-1} A T, B=Q^{-1} A Q$ , and T is not necessarily equal to Q.
A cyclic group of order $p^{n}$ (where p is a prime number) has exactly $n-1$ (nontrivial) proper subgroups. Here, the condition of being a cyclic group cannot be omitted.
There exists a function f for which $\lim _{p \rightarrow+\infty}|f|_{L^{p}(E)}=|f|_{L^{\infty}(E)}$ does not hold.
Frchet spaces, whose weak Schauder basis is always equivalent to Schauder basis.

We use $B^{\mathrm{x}}$ to represent all bounded continuous mappings from the topological space X to the real Banach space B. For $f_{1}, f_{2} \in B^{x}$, define $\begin{array}{l}\left(f_{1}+f_{2}\right)(x)=f_{1}(x)+f_{2}(x), x \in X, \\(\lambda f)(x)=\lambda f(x), \lambda \in \mathbf{R}^{1}, x \in X, \\\|f\|=\sup _{x \in X}\|f(x)\| .\end{array}$ It is clear that $B^{x}$ is a Banach space. There exists a Banach space $ B $ and compact topological spaces $ X $ and $ Y $ such that $ B^{X} $ and $ B^{Y} $ are isometrically isomorphic, but $ X $ and $ Y $ are not homeomorphic.
There exist two different topologies on a linear space that have the same closed subspaces.
$R^{2}$ in an absorbing set, It is not absorbing in the complex plane.
There exists a self-adjoint operator T that satisfies neither $T \geq 0$ nor $T \leqslant 0$.
There exists an open continuous image of some countably pseudocompact space that is not countably pseudocompact.

There exists a closed subspace M in some Hilbert space H and an orthogonal projection operator $ \boldsymbol{P}$ such that $\boldsymbol{P}(\boldsymbol{M})$ is not a closed subspace of $\boldsymbol{H} $.
There exists a divergent series, which can be rearranged to arbitrarily slow down its divergence.
There exist locally convex but not locally bounded linear topological spaces.
There exist two functions f and g such that ${f}^{2}$ and ${g}^{2}$ are both Riemann integrable, but $(f+g)^{2}$ is not Riemann integrable.
There exists a sequence of strongly convergent compact operators from one Banach space to another, whose limit is not a compact operator.

If g is a continuous one-to-one mapping on a subset of $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ to $\mathbf{R}^{2}$, and for any $p \in \mathbf{R}^{2}$, $d(p, g(p))=1$, then g must be an isometry from $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ to this subset.
There exists a dense subset in a plane that does not contain three collinear points.
There exists a mappings that map each subset to a countably compact nowhere continuous mapping.
First countable spaces and Lindelf spaces do not imply each other.
There exist strictly convex but not midpoint locally uniformly convex Banach spaces.
There exists a uniformly convergent sequence of infinitely differentiable functions whose sequence of derivatives converges nowhere.
There exists a topological space $\boldsymbol{X}$, where the points of $\boldsymbol{X}$ are functions, and its topology is equivalent to pointwise convergence, yet X is not a metrizable space.

There exists an increasing continuous function $f(x)$ on [0, 1], whose corresponding curve length cannot be expressed by the integral $\int_{0}^{1} \sqrt{1+\left[\boldsymbol{f}^{\prime}(\boldsymbol{x})\right]^{2}} dx$.
The intersection of two complete sets must be a complete set.
There exists a sequence barrel space which does not have property (s).
There exists a discontinuous function, yet $\lim _{\delta \rightarrow 0} s(\Delta)=s $.
There exists an infinite set in a normed linear space whose linear closure is not equal to the linear subspace formed by the infinite linear combinations of its elements.

There exists a vector-valued function $x(t)= \left\{\xi_{n}(t)\right\}$ defined on [0,1] with values in c, such that $\left\{\xi_{n}(t)\right\}$ uniformly converges to $\xi(t)$, and both $\xi_{n}(t)$ and $\xi(t)$ are functions of bounded variation, but $x(t)$ is not of weakly bounded variation.
There exists an (L) integrable function f on [0, 1] such that $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} n m E[x: f(x) \geqslant n]=+\infty \text {}$
There exists a function f such that $f_{yx}(x, y)$ exists but $f_{x}(x, y)$ does not exist.
There exists an uncountable metrizable completely regular space.
There exists a discrete subset on a line whose closure is an uncountable set.
There does not exist an operator with only a unique spectral point as the continuous spectrum.
There exists a non-reflexive normed linear space.
Bounded linear operators must be compact operators.
There exists a non-compact metric space that cannot be isometric with its proper subset.
If a Banach space is midpoint locally uniformly convex, then it must be locally uniformly convex.
There exists an infinite-dimensional normed linear space in which the strong and weak convergence of sequences are equivalent.
Elements that belong to $l^{p}$ but not to $l^{r}(1 \leqslant r<p<+\infty)$.
A Banach space X with a basis, where there exists a subspace $\boldsymbol{G}$ with a basis, such that no basis in G can be extended to become a basis for $\boldsymbol{X}$.
There exists a simple closed curve whose plane measure is larger than the plane measure of the bounded region it encloses.
There exists a divergent series $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} a_{n}$, such that $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\left(a_{2 n-1}+a_{2 n}\right)$ converges.

There exists a basis $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{n}\right\}$ of a Banach space, such that the subsequence $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{2 k}\right\}$ is equivalent to the basis $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{n}\right\}$, but $\left\{\boldsymbol{f}_{2 k}\right\}$ is not equivalent to $\left\{\boldsymbol{f}_{n}\right\}$, where $\left\{\boldsymbol{f}_{n}\right\}$ is the sequence of coordinate functionals for $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$.
There exists a basis for a dense subspace of a Banach space, which is not a basis for the entire space.
There exists a bijective discontinuous linear operator on a normed linear space to itself.

There exists a function $F(x, y)$, despite $F_{y}\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)=0$, in some neighborhood of $\left(x_{0}, y_{0}\right)$, the equation $F(x, y)=0$ uniquely determines $y$ as a function of $x$, $y=f(x)$, and $y_{0}=f\left(x_{0}\right)$.
The proper subgroups of a cyclic group are cyclic, but not conversely.
There exists a dense open set on the line whose complement has an infinite measure.
There exists a function for which both iterated limits exist and are equal, but the double limit does not exist.
There exists a compact convex set in a Banach space that is not the convex hull of its extreme points.
There exist Banach spaces that cannot be endowed with an equivalent uniformly convex norm.
There exists a decomposition of a Banach space that is not a Schauder decomposition.
There exists a ring $R$ without a unit element, but its subring $S$ has a unit element.

There exists a Banach space X such that the $weak^{*}$ convergence and weak convergence of sequences in $X^{*}$ coincide, but the $weak^{*}$ compactness and weak compactness of point sets in $X^{*}$ do not coincide.
There exists a ring $R$ which is a non-commutative ring, but its subring $S$ is a commutative ring.
There exists an incomplete metric space, which is homeomorphic to its completion space.
$a^{m}$ is not necessarily the smallest positive power of square of $\left(a^{m}\right)$ in terms of a.
There exists a strongest linear topology which is not locally convex.
Function f, if $f(x)$ and $\bar{f}(x)=\lim _{h \rightarrow 0}[f(x+h)-f(x-h)] / 2 h$ are both continuous at $\boldsymbol{x}=\boldsymbol{x}_{0}$, then $f^{\prime}\left(x_{0}\right)$ exists.
There exists a discontinuous mapping such that the image of an open set is an open set.
There exist two monotonic functions f, g, where f is continuous and g is discontinuous, but the composite function $f \circ g$ is a continuous monotonic function.
There exists a function whose Maclaurin series converges at only one point.
There exists a normed linear space X and x, $y \in X$, such that $\|x-y\| \geqslant \frac{1}{2}(\|x\|+\|y\|)\left\|\frac{x}{\|x\|}-\frac{y}{\|y\|}\right\|$ does not hold.

There exist functions f and g such that f is (R) integrable on [a, b], g is non-negative and (R) integrable on [a, b], yet there is no  in (a, b) that satisfies the equation $\int_{a}^{b} f(x) g(x) d x=f(\xi) \cdot \int_{a}^{b} g(x) d x$.
There exist functions that are equivalent to (R) integrable functions but are not themselves (R) integrable.
There exists an infinite-dimensional Banach space such that every reflexive subspace is finite-dimensional.
There exists a strictly increasing function with continuous derivatives, whose derivative is zero on a given perfect nowhere dense set.
There exist two bounded linear operators whose product is discontinuous with respect to the strong topology.
It is known that $\dim(\mathbf{A}V)+\dim(\mathbf{A}^{-1}(0))=  \dim (V)$, but the sum of $\mathrm{A} V$ and $\mathrm{A}^{-1}(0)$ is not necessarily V.
The sum and product of two closed linear operators do not have to be closed linear operators.

There exists a function on $[0, +\infty)$, which is positive-valued, bounded, and integrable on any finite subinterval of $[0, +\infty)$, and the integral $\int_{0}^{+\infty}(f(x))^{\alpha} d x$ converges when $\alpha=1$, but diverges when $\alpha$ is a real number not equal to 1.
There exists a countably compact but not compact topological space.

The sequence $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ is called of bounded variation if there exists a constant M, such that $\left|x_{2}-x_{1}\right| \cdot\left|x_{3}-x_{2}\right|+\cdots+\left|x_{n}-x_{n-1}\right| \leqslant M, n=2,3, \cdots.$ There exists a convergent sequence that is not of bounded variation.
There exists a non-reflexive normed linear space whose conjugate space is reflexive.
There exists a decreasing sequence of measurable sets $\left\{E_{n}\right\}$ such that $m\left(\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} E_{n}\right) \neq \lim _{n \rightarrow \infty} m E_{n}$.
For a continuous monotonic function g and a continuous function f, it holds that $\int_{0}^{1} f(x) d g(x)=\int_{0}^{1} f(x) g^{\prime}(x) d x$.
A finite group cannot be isomorphic to its proper subgroup, but an infinite group can be isomorphic to its proper subgroup.

If two weighted shift operators $\boldsymbol{A}$ and B with weights $\left\{\alpha_{n}\right\}$ and $\left\{\beta_{n}\right\}$ are unitarily equivalent, then for all n we have $\left|\alpha_{n}\right|=\left|\beta_{n}\right|$.

There exists a sequence of measurable sets $\left\{E_{n}\right\}$ contained within a finite interval, such that $\operatorname{lim} _{n \rightarrow \infty} E_{n}$ exists, but $m\left(\varlimsup_{n \rightarrow \infty} E_{n}\right) \neq m\left(\varliminf_{n \rightarrow \infty} E_{n}\right)$.
There exists a bounded linear operator with an unbounded inverse operator.

A biorthogonal sequence $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{n}\right\}$ with $\left\{\boldsymbol{f}_{n}\right\}$, where $\left\{\boldsymbol{f}_{n}\right\}$ is a bounded complete basic sequence, but $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$ is not a shrinking basic sequence.
There exists a series in a Banach space that converges but not unconditionally converges.
There exist two functions, neither of which is of bounded variation, that form a composite function of bounded variation.
The condition of integrability of the control function in the Lebesgue Dominated Convergence Theorem cannot be removed.
The Young convergence criterion and the Dini convergence criterion do not imply each other.
All bounded linear operators in the space $L^{2}[0,1]$ are integral operators.
In a ring, there exist $a \neq 0, b \neq 0$ where $a b=0$. At this point, a is called a left zero divisor in this ring, and b is called a right zero divisor.
Dini's convergence criterion and Jordan's convergence criterion do not imply each other.

The generalized (R) double integral $\int_{0}^{1} \int_{0}^{1} f(x, y) d x d y $ exists, and for each $ x \in [0,1]$, the integral $ \int_{0}^{1} f(x, y) d y $ exists, but the iterated integral $\int_{0}^{1} d x \int_{0}^{1} f(x,y) d y$ may not exist for the function f.
There exists a topological space that is not a $T_{0}$ space.
An (R) integrable function f does not necessarily make $g(x)=\int_{0}^{x} f(t) d t$ differentiable everywhere.
There exist metric linear spaces that cannot be normed.
There exist differentiable complex-valued functions where the mean value theorem fails.
The sum function of two functions, each having the intermediate value property, must have the intermediate value property.
There exists a strict inductive limit of a sequence of metrizable spaces, which is non-metrizable.
There exists a non-negative (L) integrable function on $R^{1}$, so that for any non-empty interval $[a, b]$, it is not essentially bounded on $[a, b]$.
There exists a nonlinear isometric mapping.
There exists a strictly increasing absolutely continuous function whose inverse is not absolutely continuous.
The condition $ m E<+\infty$ in the Vitali theorem cannot be removed.
There exists a function with bounded variation on [0,1] that is discontinuous on every non-empty subinterval of [0,1].
A non-zero continuous linear functional on a uniformly convex normed linear space must attain its maximum value on the closed unit ball.
There exist vector-valued functions that are weakly measurable but not strongly measurable.
There exists a linear isomorphism with a strictly convex Banach space, whose quotient space is not linearly isomorphic to any strictly convex space.
There exists a divergent sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ such that $\left\{\left|a_{n}\right|\right\}$ converges.
There exists a trigonometric series that is not a Fourier-Lebesgue series, but it is a Fourier-Stieltjes series.
For the unit ball U in the space $c_{0}$, there exists a non-expansive mapping from U to U with no fixed point.
There exists an (L) integrable function whose conjugate function is not (L) integrable on any non-empty closed interval.
There exists a function f, such that $\max _{y} \min _{x} f(x, y)<\min _{x} \max _{y} f(x, y)$.
There exists a $weak^{*}$ separable but not $weak^{*}$ sequentially separable conjugate space.
There exists a sequence of functionals that converges $weak^{*}$ but not weakly.
There exists a subsymmetric basis in a certain Banach space, which is not a symmetric basis.
There exists a family of metrizable topological spaces whose product space is not metrizable.
There exists an infinite topological space that does not contain an infinite set of isolated points.
There exists a $\sigma$-compact but not compact topological space.
There exists a non-weak compactly generated space, whose conjugate space is weak compactly generated.
The epimorphism of a group's endomorphism is necessarily an automorphism.
A subspace of a finite space over ring R is an example of an infinite space.
There exists a sequence of operators, each with a spectrum of {0}, yet the spectral radius of their direct sum equals 1.
There is no mutual implication between uniform convergence and mean convergence.
There exist two absolutely continuous functions that form a non-absolutely continuous composite function.

There exist a compact set $F_{1}$ and a closed set $F_{2}$ in a complete metric space, such that for any $\boldsymbol{x} \in \boldsymbol{F}_{1}, \boldsymbol{y} \in \boldsymbol{F}_{2}$ we always have $\boldsymbol{d}(\boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{y})>\boldsymbol{d}\left(\boldsymbol{F}_{1}, \boldsymbol{F}_{2}\right)$.
There exists a subset A of some Banach space X, such that the linear subspace spanned by every infinite subset of A is dense in X.

If there exists a surjection from a ring $R$ to a non-empty set $\bar{R}$, such that $R$ and $\bar{R}$ are homomorphic with respect to both addition and multiplication, then $\bar{R}$ is also a ring. The converse is false, that is, there exists a surjection from a non-empty set $R$ to a ring $\bar{R}$, such that $R$ and $\bar{R}$ are homomorphic with respect to both addition and multiplication, but $R$ is not necessarily a ring.
There exists a convergent trigonometric series that is not the Fourier series of any (L) integrable function.
A normal operator must be a self-adjoint operator.
There exists an infinite-dimensional normed linear space that is isometrically isomorphic to one of its proper subspaces.
There exist two non-negative divergent sequences whose sum is a convergent sequence.
There exists a divergent improper integral with a finite Cauchy principal value.
There exists a strictly increasing continuous function that is not differentiable everywhere.
There exists a vector-valued function that is weakly absolutely continuous but not absolutely continuous.
Young's criterion for convergence and de la Valle Poussin's criterion for convergence do not imply each other.
There exists a normal operator T and an orthogonal projection operator P such that PTP is not a normal operator.
There exist continuous linear operators and closed linear operators do not imply each other.
The product of a family of uniformly convex Banach spaces on a uniformly convex Banach space must be uniformly convex.
Examples where the $n(n \geqslant 3)$-ary associative law does not hold
There exists a weakly contractive mapping on the unit closed ball in some Banach space that has no fixed point.
There exists an unbounded linear operator whose inverse is bounded.
Separable spaces and Lindelf spaces do not imply each other.
Contractible matrices are necessarily equivalent matrices, but not vice versa.
A symmetric operator must be a self-adjoint operator.
There exists a uniformly convergent sequence of differentiable functions whose sequence of derivatives' limit is not equal to the derivative of the limit function.
There exists a subspace M of a normed linear space and a point $x_{0}$ such that the nearest element from M to $x_{0}$ is not unique.
All proper subgroups of a non-abelian group are non-abelian?
There exists a differentiable function f, whose absolute value function $|{f}|$ is not differentiable.
There exists a continuous function at known points $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}$ that does not have a derivative.
There exists a metrizable space, whose strong double dual is not a metrizable space.
There exists a Lindelf space that satisfies the first countability axiom and is separable, but does not satisfy the second countability axiom.
There exist discontinuous functions that have derivatives everywhere (not necessarily finite).
There exists a differentiable function of bounded variation f, such that $ V(x)=\int_{0}^{x}\left|f^{\prime}(t)\right| d t $ is not differentiable.
There exists a function on the Cantor ternary set that is continuous but nowhere continuous on its adjacent intervals.
If for every positive integer p, $\lim _{n \rightarrow \infty}\left(a_{n+p}-a_{n}\right)=0$, then the sequence $\left\{a_{n}\right\}$ converges.
The principle of Hchy's choice also holds for the family of functions with strongly bounded variation taking values in c.

In the polynomial $P[x]$, the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is $d(x)$. Then there exist polynomials $u(x)$ and $v(x)$ in $P[x]$ such that $d(x)=u(x)(f(x)+v(x) g(x))$, but (i) the reverse is not true. That is, the equation holds, but $d(x)$ is not necessarily the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$; (ii) the $u(x)$ and $v(x)$ that satisfy the equation are not unique.
There exists a function that is continuous on [0, 1] but not of bounded variation on any non-empty subinterval of [0, 1].

There exists a bounded linear operator P on some Hilbert space, satisfying $\|P x\|^{2}=  \langle\boldsymbol{P} \boldsymbol{x}, \boldsymbol{x}\rangle $, but $\boldsymbol{P} $ is not a projection operator.
There exist differentiable but not continuously differentiable functions.

There exists a vector-valued function $x(t)= \left\{\xi_{n}(t)\right\}$ defined on [0,1] and taking values in space c, such that each $\xi_{n}(t)$ satisfies the Lipschitz condition, yet $x(t)$ is not a function of strongly bounded variation.
There exists a Banach space that is isometrically isomorphic to its second conjugate space but is not reflexive itself.

The Eisenstein criterion tells us: If  $f(x)=a_{n} x^{n}+a_{n-1} x^{n-1}+\cdots+a_{0}$ is a polynomial with integer coefficients, there exists a prime p such that i) $p \nmid a_{n}$; ii) $p \mid a_{i}, i=0,1, \cdots, n-1$; iii) $p^{2} \nmid a_{0}$. Then $f(x)$ is irreducible over the rational numbers. However, if no such prime p can be found, we cannot determine its reducibility.
There exists a differentiable function whose partial derivatives are all discontinuous.
Closed set $\boldsymbol{F}$, must ensure $\overline{\left(\boldsymbol{F}^{\circ}\right)} = \boldsymbol{F}$.
For any continuous linear operator T, there exists a constant M such that $d(T x, 0) \leqslant M d(x, 0)$.
There exist lower semi-continuous but not continuous functionals.

A sequence of positive integers $ a_{1}<a_{2}<\cdots  $ and a compact set C, such that for any $x \in C $, $\sin a_{n} x \rightarrow 0(n \rightarrow \infty)$, then $ \{\sin a_{n} x \}$ is uniformly convergent on C.
There exists an inductive limit of a family of complete locally convex spaces, which is not complete.
There exist four pairwise disjoint planar regions with a common boundary.
In the ring of integers $Z$, there exists a maximal subring containing 3 but not containing 5.
There exists a mapping from one topological space to another that is open, but neither continuous nor closed.
There exists a mapping f from a topological space X to Y that is a semi-homeomorphism, but its restriction $f \mid A$ on some subset A of X is not a semi-homeomorphism from A to $f(A)$.
There exist countably many locally connected spaces, whose product space is not locally connected.
There exists a Banach space whose norm is not Gateaux differentiable.
There exist two different topologies on a linear space that have the same bounded sets.
For the mapping f, $f(A) \subset f(B)$ does not necessarily imply $A \subset B$.
There exists a function on [0, 1] with uncountable discontinuities, which is the limit of a sequence of continuous functions.
There exist infinite products that converge but do not converge absolutely.
There exist projection operators whose norm is not 1.

There exists a sequence $\left\{x_{n}\right\}$, which is a basis for the Banach spaces $\left(X,\|\cdot\|_{X}\right)$ and $\left(Y,\|\cdot\|_{Y}\right)$, but not a basis for $\left(\boldsymbol{X} \cap \boldsymbol{Y},\|\cdot\|=\|\cdot\|_{x}+\|\cdot\|_{Y}\right)$.
Given any natural number $n$, a topological space can be constructed with an $n$-point compactification, but for $m>n$, there exists no $m$-point compactification space.
Almost everywhere convergence and mean convergence do not imply each other.
There exists a function that is uniformly continuous on both open intervals $I_{1}$ and $I_{2}$, but not uniformly continuous on $I_{1} \cup I_{2}$.
There exists a set that is metrically bounded but not bounded in a metric linear space.
There exists a sequence in some topological space that converges to every point in that space.
There exists a bounded function that is ($\boldsymbol{L}$) integrable but not (R) integrable.
There exists an uncountable number of countable measurable spaces whose product space is not normal.
There exists a bounded closed convex subset in a normed linear space that does not have the fixed point property.
There exists a measurable function f on $R^{1}$ such that $ \sup _{t \in R^{1}} \mid f(x+t)-f(x-t)\mid $ is not measurable.
There exists a function for which only one iterated limit exists.
There exists a subspace of a -compact space that is not -compact.
There exist two operators whose joint numerical radius is not equal to the product of their numerical radii.
There exists a Banach space X such that every infinite-dimensional complementable subspace of X is linearly isomorphic to X.
A closed subset $X_{0}$ of [0,1] and two commutative continuous mappings $\boldsymbol{f}, \boldsymbol{g}$ from $X_{0}$ to $X_{0}$ must have commutative continuous extensions.
There exist two continuous but unequal maps from a topological space X to another topological space Y, which take the same values on a dense subset of X.
Generally, $(A B)^{k} \neq A^{k} B^{k}$
The convex hull of a bounded set in a linear metric space is necessarily bounded

There exists a non-normal basis $\left\{\boldsymbol{x}_{n}\right\}$ of a Banach space such that the sequence of coordinate functionals $\left\{\boldsymbol{f}_{n}\right\}$ is a normal basis of $\overline{\operatorname{span}}\left\{\boldsymbol{f}_{n}\right\}$.
There exist non-separable Banach spaces with a Schauder decomposition.
There exists a divergent series $\sum_{n=1} a_{n} $, such that the infinite product $ \prod_{n=1}\left(1+a_{n}\right) $ converges.
The continuous function in Luzin's theorem cannot be replaced by a polynomial.
There exists a uniformly convergent parameterized integral that cannot use a parameter-independent convergent integral as a majorant function.
There exist closed subspaces that are algebraically complementary but not topologically complementary.

Let $f: S \to T$ be a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Let $f^{-1} \subseteq T \times S$ be the [[Definition:Inverse of Mapping|inverse]] of $f$: :$f^{-1} := \set {\tuple {t, s}: \map f s = t}$ Let $f^{-1}$ itself be a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]: :$\forall y \in T: \tuple {y, x_1} \in f^{-1} \land \tuple {y, x_2} \in f^{-1} \implies x_1 = x_2$ and :$\forall y \in T: \exists x \in S: \tuple {y, x} \in f$ Then $f^{-1}$ is called the '''   '''.
Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Sphere (Geometry)|sphere]]. A '''   ''' on $S$ is a [[Definition:Semicircle|semicircle]] consisting of half of a [[Definition:Great Circle|great circle]] on $S$.

'''   ''' was one of the original four [[Definition:Philosophical Element|elements]] that were postulated by the [[Definition:Pythagoreans|Pythagoreans]] to compose the [[Definition:Physical Universe|Universe]]. It had its [[Definition:Natural Place|natural place]] around the rim of the sphere of [[Definition:Philosophical Element/Water|water]].

Let $A$ and $B$ be [[Definition:Commutative Ring with Unity|commutative ring with unity]]. Let $f : A \to B$ be a [[Definition:unital Ring Homomorphism|ring homomorphism]]. Let $\mathfrak a \subseteq A$ be an [[Definition:Ideal of Ring|ideal]]. The '''   ''' of $\mathfrak a$ by $f$ is the [[Definition:Generated Ideal of Ring|ideal generated]] by its [[Definition:Image of Subset under Mapping|image]] under $f$: :$\mathfrak a^e = \left\langle f(\mathfrak a) \right\rangle$

Let $G$ be a [[Definition:Group|group]]. Let $S$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]]. Let $*: G \times S \to S$ be a [[Definition:Group Action|group action]]. The [[Definition:Group Action|group action]] is '''   ''' {{iff}} for any $x, y \in S$ there exists $g \in G$ such that $g * x = y$. That is, {{iff}} for all $x \in S$: :$\Orb x = S$ where $\Orb x$ denotes the [[Definition:Orbit (Group Theory)|orbit]] of $x \in S$ under $*$.

Let $\struct {\R, +, \times, \le}$ be the [[Definition:Field of Real Numbers|field of real numbers]]. Let $\N$ be the [[Definition:Natural Numbers in Real Numbers|natural numbers in $\R$]]. Then the '''   ''' of $\N$ is the [[Definition:Restriction of Relation|restriction]] of $\le$ to $\N$.

:$1$ '''   ''' $= \dfrac 1 6$ [[Definition:Scrupulus|scrupulus]] $= \dfrac 1 {144}$ [[Definition:Uncia|uncia]]. Its value in modern units is estimated to be approximately $2.9$ [[Definition:Grain|grains]], or approximately $0.19$ [[Definition:Gram|grams]].
