Let $G$ be a [[Definition:Game|game]]. The '''   ''' of the [[Definition:Solution of Game|solution]] of $G$ treats $G$ in isolation, as a singular event, and, under the assumption that the [[Definition:Player|players]] are [[Definition:Rational Player|rational]], deduces the outcome of $G$ based on the [[Definition:Model of Rational Choice|rational model]].

Let $R$ be a [[Definition:Ring (Abstract Algebra)|ring]]. Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a [[Definition:Strictly Positive Integer|(strictly) positive integer]]. Let $\map {\mathcal M_R} n$ denote the [[Definition:Matrix Space|$n \times n$ matrix space]] over $R$. Let $+$ denote the operation of [[Definition:Matrix Entrywise Addition|matrix entrywise addition]]. Let $\times$ be (temporarily) used to denote the operation of [[Definition:Matrix Product (Conventional)|conventional matrix multiplication]].  The [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structure]]: :$\struct {\map {\mathcal M_R} n, +, \times}$ is known as the '''   '''

Let $\closedint a b$ be a [[Definition:Closed Real Interval|closed real interval]]. Let $f: \closedint a b \to \R$ be a [[Definition:Bounded Real-Valued Function|bounded]] [[Definition:Real Function|real function]]. The '''   ''' is defined as: :$\displaystyle \underline {\int_a^b} \map f x \rd x = \sup_P \map L P$ where: :the [[Definition:Supremum of Real-Valued Function|supremum]] is taken over all [[Definition:Subdivision (Real Analysis)|subdivisions]] $P$ of $\closedint a b$ :$\map L P$ denotes the [[Definition:Lower Sum|lower sum]] of $f$ on $\closedint a b$ belonging to $P$.

Let $\left({R, +, \cdot}\right)$ be a [[Definition:Ring (Abstract Algebra)|ring]]. Let: :$(1): \quad \cdots \longrightarrow M_i \stackrel{d_i} {\longrightarrow} M_{i + 1} \stackrel {d_{i + 1}} {\longrightarrow} M_{i + 2} \stackrel {d_{i + 2}} {\longrightarrow} \cdots$ be a [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] of [[Definition:Module|$R$-modules]] $M_i$ and [[Definition:R-Algebraic Structure Homomorphism|$R$-module homomorphisms]] $d_i$. Then the [[Definition:Sequence|sequence]] $(1)$ is '''   ''' {{iff}}: : $\forall i: \operatorname{Im} d_i = \ker d_{i + 1}$ where $\operatorname{Im}$ and $\ker$ denote the [[Definition:Image of Mapping|image]] and [[Definition:Kernel (Abstract Algebra)|kernel]] of mappings respectively.

Let $m \in \Z$ be an [[Definition:Integer|integer]]. Let $\Z_m$ be the [[Definition:Integers Modulo m|set of integers modulo $m$]]: :$\Z_m = \set {\eqclass 0 m, \eqclass 1 m, \ldots, \eqclass {m - 1} m}$ where $\eqclass x m$ is the [[Definition:Residue Class|residue class of $x$ modulo $m$]]. The [[Definition:Binary Operation|operation]] of '''   ''' is defined on $\Z_m$ as: :$\eqclass a m -_m \eqclass b m = \eqclass {a - b} m$
'''   ''' is an archaic name for $10^9$.

An '''   ''' is the amount of [[Definition:Work|work]] needed to move a unit of [[Definition:Electric Charge|electric charge]] from a given [[Definition:Reference Point|reference point]] to a specific [[Definition:Point|point]] in an [[Definition:Electric Field|electric field]] without producing an [[Definition:Acceleration|acceleration]]. The [[Definition:Reference Point|reference point]] is usually either [[Definition:Earth|Earth]] or a [[Definition:Point at Infinity|point at infinity]], although any [[Definition:Point|point]] can be used.

Every [[Definition:Body|body]] which has [[Definition:Mass|mass]] influences every other body which has mass, according to [[Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation]]. Thus any body can be considered as being surrounded by a [[Definition:Field (Physics)|field]] given rise to by its mass, called a '''   '''. Its value $\mathbf g$ at any point is given by: :$\mathbf g = \dfrac {G M} {d^3} \mathbf d$ where: :$G$ is the [[Definition:Gravitational Constant|gravitational constant]]; :$M$ is the [[Definition:Mass|mass]] of the [[Definition:Body|body]]; :$\mathbf d$ is the [[Definition:Displacement|displacement vector]] from the point to the [[Definition:Center of Gravity|center of gravity]] of the [[Definition:Body|body]], whose [[Definition:Magnitude|magnitude]] is $d$. [[Category:Definitions/Gravity]] a6klacxrfb4shh9tbts35rik9o2b3gs

Let $P: \C \to \C$ and $Q: \C \to \C$ be [[Definition:Complex Polynomial Function|polynomial functions]] on the set of [[Definition:Complex Number|complex numbers]]. Let $S$ be the set $\C$ from which all the [[Definition:Root of Polynomial|roots of $Q$]] have been removed. That is: :$S = \C \setminus \set {z \in \C: \map Q z = 0}$ Then the equation $y = \dfrac {\map P z} {\map Q z}$ defines a [[Definition:Complex Function|function]] from $S$ to $\C$. Such a [[Definition:Complex Function|function]] is a '''   '''.

Let $\mathbf A$ be a [[Definition:Square Matrix|square matrix]] over a [[Definition:Set|set]] $S$. $\mathbf A$ is '''   ''' {{iff}}: :$\mathbf A = \mathbf A^\intercal$ where $\mathbf A^\intercal$ is the [[Definition:Transpose of Matrix|transpose of $\mathbf A$]].

Let $\left({S, \circ}\right)$ be an [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structure]]. Let $\mathcal R$ be a [[Definition:Congruence Relation|congruence relation]] on $\left({S, \circ}\right)$. Let $S / \mathcal R$ be the [[Definition:Quotient Set|quotient set of $S$ by $\mathcal R$]]. Let $\circ_\mathcal R$ be the [[Definition:Operation Induced on Quotient Set|operation induced on $S / \mathcal R$ by $\circ$]]. The '''   ''' is the [[Definition:Algebraic Structure|algebraic structure]]: : $\left({S / \mathcal R, \circ_\mathcal R}\right)$
A [[Definition:Geometric Figure|geometric figure]] is said to be '''   ''' by its [[Definition:Boundary (Geometry)|boundary]] or [[Definition:Boundary (Geometry)|boundaries]].
The '''   ''' of $K$ is the [[Definition:Automorphism Group of Field Extension|automorphism group]] $\Aut {\overline K \mid K}$ of its [[Definition:Algebraic Closure|algebraic closure]].

The '''   ''' $(A) \Z_{\ge 0} \times \Z_{\ge 0} \to \Z_{> 0}$ is an [[Definition:Integer-Valued Function|integer-valued function]] defined on the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Ordered Pair|ordered pairs]] of [[Definition:Positive Integer|positive integers]] as: :$A \left({x, y}\right) = \begin{cases} y + 1 & : x = 0 \\ A \left({x - 1, 1}\right) & : x > 0, y = 0 \\ A \left({x - 1, A \left({x, y - 1}\right)}\right) & : \text{otherwise} \end{cases}$

The '''   ''' is defined as $2$ raised to the [[Definition:Power to Real Number|power]] of the [[Definition:Square Root|square root]] of $2$: :$2^{\sqrt 2}$ Its [[Definition:Decimal Expansion|decimal expansion]] begins: :$2^{\sqrt 2} \approx 2 \cdotp 66514 \, 4$ {{OEIS|A007507}} {{NamedforDef|Alexander Osipovich Gelfond|name2 = Theodor Schneider|cat = Gelfond|cat2 = Schneider}}

Let $C$ and $D$ be [[Definition:Category|categories]]. Let $F : C \to D$ be a [[Definition:Covariant Functor|covariant functor]]. The functor $F$ is '''   ''' {{iff}} it is [[Definition:Full Functor|full]] and [[Definition:Faithful Functor|faithful]]. [[Category:Definitions/Category Theory]] i96p1iro3gt54jq9tgt3qy5ryxnud99

Let $\left({X_i, \Sigma_i}\right)$ be [[Definition:Measurable Space|measurable spaces]], with $i \in I$ for some [[Definition:Index Set|index set]] $I$. Let $X$ be a [[Definition:Set|set]], and let, for $i \in I$, $f_i: X \to X_i$ be a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]]. Then the '''   ''', $\sigma \left({f_i: i \in I}\right)$, is the smallest [[Definition:Sigma-Algebra|$\sigma$-algebra]] on $X$ such that every $f_i$ is [[Definition:Measurable Mapping|$\sigma \left({f_i: i \in I}\right) \, / \, \Sigma_i$-measurable]]. That is, $\sigma \left({f_i: i \in I}\right)$ is subject to: :$(1):\quad \forall i \in I: \forall E_i \in \Sigma_i: f_i^{-1} \left({E_i}\right) \in \sigma \left({f_i: i \in I}\right)$ :$(2):\quad \sigma \left({f_i: i \in I}\right) \subseteq \Sigma$ for all [[Definition:Sigma-Algebra|$\sigma$-algebras]] $\Sigma$ on $X$ satisfying $(1)$ In fact, $\sigma \left({f_i: i \in I}\right)$ always exists, and is unique, as proved on [[Existence and Uniqueness of Sigma-Algebra Generated by Collection of Mappings]].
Let $\N$ be the [[Definition:Natural Numbers|natural numbers]]. Let $n \in \N$ and $m \in \N_{>0}$. Then '''   ''' is defined as: :$m \divides n \iff \exists p \in \N: m \times p = n$

A '''   ''' is a [[Definition:Rational Number|rational number]] whose [[Definition:Absolute Value|absolute value]] is greater than $1$, expressed in the form $r = n \frac p q$ where: : $p$ and $q$ are [[Definition:Integer|integers]] such that $p < q$ : $r = n + \dfrac p q$

A '''   ''' is a [[Definition:Statement|statement]] defining a [[Definition:Condition|condition]] that is required to be fulfilled in order to solve a problem in the [[Definition:Calculus of Variations|calculus of variations]].

Let $p$ be a [[Definition:Variable|variable]] whose [[Definition:Domain of Variable|domain]] is a [[Definition:Subset|subset]] of the [[Definition:Real Number|set of real numbers]] $\R$. Let $\closedint a b$ be a [[Definition:Closed Real Interval|closed real interval]] for some $a, b \in \R: a \le b$. Let $f: \closedint a b \to \R$ be a [[Definition:Real Function|real function]] defined on the [[Definition:Domain of Mapping|domain]] $\closedint a b$. Let $\map K {p, x}$ be a [[Definition:Real-Valued Function|real-valued function]] defined for all $p$ in its [[Definition:Domain of Variable|domain]] and all $x \in \closedint a b$. Let $\map f x \map K {p, x}$ be [[Definition:Integrable Function|integrable]] {{WRT|Integration}} $x$ for all $p$ in its [[Definition:Domain of Variable|domain]] and all $x \in \closedint a b$. Consider the [[Definition:Real Function|real function]] $\map F p$ defined as: :$\map F p = \displaystyle \int_a^b \map f x \map K {p, x} \rd x$ Then $\map F p$ is an '''   ''' of $\map f x$.

Let $x$ be a [[Definition:set|set]]. For each [[Definition:Natural Number|natural number]] $n \in \N_{\ge 0}$ let: : $\bigcup^n x = \underbrace{\bigcup \bigcup \cdots \bigcup}_n x$ Then the '''   ''' of $x$ is the [[Definition:Union of Set of Sets|union]] of the sets: :$\left\{ {x}\right\}, x, \bigcup x, \bigcup^2 x, \dots, \bigcup^n x, \dots$

$f$ is '''   ''' {{iff}}: :$(1): \quad f$ is [[Definition:Continuous Real Function|continuous]] :$(2): \quad$ there exists a [[Definition:Finite Subdivision|finite subdivision]] $\set {x_0, \ldots, x_n}$ of $\closedint a b$, $x_0 = a$ and $x_n = b$, such that: ::$(2.1): \quad f$ is [[Definition:Continuously Differentiable Real Function|continuously differentiable]] on $\openint {x_{i - 1}} {x_i}$ for every $i \in \set {1, \ldots, n}$ ::$(2.2): \quad$ the [[Definition:One-Sided Limit of Real Function|one-sided limits]] $\displaystyle \lim_{x \mathop \to {x_{i - 1}}^+} \map {f'} x$ and $\displaystyle \lim_{x \mathop \to {x_i}^-} \map {f'} x$ exist for every $i \in \set {1, \ldots, n}$.
A '''   ''' is a [[Definition:Subcover|subcover]] $\mathcal V \subseteq \mathcal U$ which is [[Definition:Countable Cover|countable]].
The [[Definition:Integer Sequence|sequence]] of '''   ''' begins: :$6, 12, 18, 20, 24, 28, 30, \ldots$

The '''   ''' is the [[Definition:Function|function]] $\pi: \R \to \Z$ which counts the number of [[Definition:Prime Number|primes]] less than or equal to some [[Definition:Real Number|real number]]. That is: :$\displaystyle \forall x \in \R: \map \pi x = \sum_{\substack {p \mathop \in \mathbb P \\ p \mathop \le x} } 1$ where $\mathbb P$ denotes the [[Definition:Set|set]] of [[Definition:Prime Number|prime numbers]].

Let $F$ be a [[Definition:Field (Abstract Algebra)|field]]. Let $P: F \to F$ and $Q: F \to F$ be [[Definition:Polynomial Function (Abstract Algebra)|polynomial functions]] on $F$. Let $S$ be the set $F$ from which all the [[Definition:Root of Polynomial|roots of $Q$]] have been removed. That is: :$S = F \setminus \set {x \in F: \map Q x = 0}$ Then the equation $y = \dfrac {\map P x} {\map Q x}$ defines a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] from $S$ to $F$. Such a [[Definition:Mapping|mapping]] is called a '''   '''.

Let $f: \N^k \to \N$ and $g: \N^{k+2} \to \N$ be [[Definition:Partial Function|partial functions]]. Let $\tuple {n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_k} \in \N^k$. Note that $\map h {n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_k, n}$ is defined only when: :$\map h {n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_k, n - 1}$ is defined :$\map g {n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_k, n - 1, \map h {n_1, n_2, \ldots, n_k, n - 1} }$ is defined.
